bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Repetti, January 16, 1947

div1.p: Hench inquires of Mrs. Repetti if her husband was related to Dr. James Repetti, a medical officer stationed at Columbia Barracks during the time of the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Repetti, January 16, 1947
div1.opener:
January 16, 1947
Mrs. George Repetti
5 Lake Avenue
Broadmoor, Colorado
My dear Thelma:

p.del:
When I saw you in October you asked
me to send you the name of a St. Louis internist
upon whom Nancy might call if necessary. May I
give you the following name--Dr. R. D. Williams,
114 North Taylor, St. Louis, Missouri.

div1.p:
I have for some years been interested
in the story of Walter Reed and the “Conquest
of Yellow Fever.” One of the medical officers
in Cuba at that time at the hospital where the
work was done was Dr. John J. Repetti, Contract
Surgeon who lived in Washington before the
Spanish-American War and returned to Washington,
D. C. and practiced medicine there. Did George
have any relatives who were American medical
officers in Cuba in 1900? I have often wondered
about the similarity in names.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
